unit.utterance: Mian foran ishen mian adherfin arkondissan je mian ftoshin.
unit.utterance_translation: One time there were a rich sister and a poor one.

unit.utterance: I ftoshi ishen tria pekk'a, mian koruan je dhk'o pallikarka.
unit.utterance_translation: The poor one had three children, one girl and two boys.

unit.utterance: I arkondissa monon mian koruan ishen.
unit.utterance_translation: The rich one had only one girl.

unit.utterance: I arkondissa epernen tin kathimera j ezimonnen tis psumia j epulen je then tis eoken enan vukkon psumin na fai ute jinis ute ton moron tis.
unit.utterance_translation: The rich one took her every day and kneaded bread and sold it, and she did not give her one bite bread for her to eat, neither to her nor her children.

unit.utterance: Monon eminiskan sta sherka tis ta zimarika je ta mandilia tis me ton korn'axton j epiennen kathi nixta j andinassen ta sherka tis, eplinnisken ta, tin pok'an tis andinassen tin j epk'annen jind alevrin j exoghlan llion neron san tin ghrutan j etroan ta mora tis j eppeftan tin nixtan j ejimundan, xortasmena me jinon to neron.
unit.utterance_translation: It's only that dough stayed on her hands and her handkerchiefs with korn'axtos (?) and she went every night and shook her hands, washed them, shook the flour off her apron and took it and boiled a little water and made ghruta and her children ate and lied down at night and slept, full from that water.

unit.utterance: Kathimera sinexian etsi ekamnen.
unit.utterance_translation: She did so every day.

unit.utterance: I kumera tis arkondissas irten mian imeran &ya na kuveg'azun.
unit.utterance_translation: The rich woman's best woman came one day to have a talk.

unit.utterance: Ta mora tis atherfis tis ekaxundan jame je to moron jinis tis arkondissas mes stin mesin.
unit.utterance_translation: Her sister's children sat there and her -the rich sister's- child in the middle.

unit.utterance: Paratira, kumera, ;ti kalon eni tu Theu!
unit.utterance_translation: Look, best woman, how good it is, this child of God!

unit.utterance: Emenan to moron mu me to ghalan tu, me to chain tu, me to sughluthin tu, me ta afta tu, oti xeli i oreksi tu &na to taiso.
unit.utterance_translation: As for me, my child has its milk, its tea, its kebab, this and that, whatever it wants I feed it.

unit.utterance: Tuta monon lliin ghrutan pu ta sherka tis manas tus je pu tin skonin ton pothk'on tis je tis kuruklas tis je xore *inda kochina en jina *j emenan inda lois en jitrina!
unit.utterance_translation: These ones have only a little ghruta from their mother's hands and from the dust on her feet and on her headscarf, and look how red they are, while mine are yellow!

unit.utterance: Troi to kkismettin tu moru su ta mora tis.
unit.utterance_translation: The fate of your child eats her children.

unit.utterance: Prepi kathi nixta na tin plinniskis, na tin iksiskonizis j etsi na paenni esso tis, yati ine to kkismettin tu moru su.
unit.utterance_translation: Every night you have to wash her, dust her, and only like that should she go home, because it is the fate of your child.

unit.utterance: Etsi?
unit.utterance_translation: Like this?

unit.utterance: Etsi, kalo!
unit.utterance_translation: Like this, of course!

unit.utterance: Malista!
unit.utterance_translation: Ok!

unit.utterance: Etel'osa tin dhoul'an, atherfin, eoni, enna pao spitin mu.
unit.utterance_translation: Sister, I finished my job, I will go home.

unit.utterance: Pomine, pomine.
unit.utterance_translation: Wait, wait.

unit.utterance: Na plittis, n andinaxtis, efkar ta mandil'a su, andinakse ta, tes pothk'es su, j eyoni eth thelo na paris tipote sto spitin su popse.
unit.utterance_translation: Wash, dust yourself off, take off your scarfs, shake them and your aprons, and I don't want you to take anything home tonight.

unit.utterance: Yati, atherfin?
unit.utterance_translation: Why, sister?

unit.utterance: Etsi xelo!
unit.utterance_translation: Because I want it to be this way.

unit.utterance: Epien i jeneka esso tis.
unit.utterance_translation: The woman went home.

unit.utterance: *O, mamma, yati eplittikes j en mas eferes na famen?
unit.utterance_translation: Oh, mum, why did you wash and you did not bring us (something) to eat?

unit.utterance: *Ti na kamo pedhk'a mu?
unit.utterance_translation: What can I do, my children?

unit.utterance: I thk'a sas evalen me j eplittika j andinaksa ta ruxa mu j etsi na rto.
unit.utterance_translation: Your aunt ordered me to wash and shake my clothes and come like this.

unit.utterance: E, je pu pinumen, mamma!
unit.utterance_translation: But we're hungry, mum.

unit.utterance: Ei, mana mu, minete pa stin karkolan &je na pao dhaame stin yitonissan na umen an eshi kanenan psumin je dhoki mu je fero sas je fate.
unit.utterance_translation: Oh, my children, stay on the bed and I will go to the neighbour to see if she has some bread, so I can bring it to you to eat.

unit.utterance: Ei, mamma!
unit.utterance_translation: Ok, mum.

unit.utterance: Pk'anni tin stratan, andis na pai stin yitonissan na tis pi na tis dhoki enan psumin, epk'aen tin stratan na pai na xathi.
unit.utterance_translation: She starts walking on the road, instead of going to the neighbour to ask for some bread, she started walking on the road in order to get lost.

unit.utterance: San epiennen, ivren ena chatirin olofoton.
unit.utterance_translation: As she was walking she came across a lighted tent.

unit.utterance: Xa, enna mbo dhamesa, lali.
unit.utterance_translation: Ha, I will go in here, she says.

unit.utterance: Embin jimesa.
unit.utterance_translation: She went in there.

unit.utterance: Kalispera sas.
unit.utterance_translation: Good evening to you.

unit.utterance: O, kalos tin, pos os dha?
unit.utterance_translation: Oh, welcome, how did you end up here?

unit.utterance: Pinas?
unit.utterance_translation: Are you hungry?

unit.utterance: Pino, kalo!
unit.utterance_translation: Of course I'm hungry.

unit.utterance: Eokan tis mian pittan je tris el'es.
unit.utterance_translation: They gave her a pie and three olives.

unit.utterance: E, fae!
unit.utterance_translation: So, eat!

unit.utterance: Enna to paro ton moron mu.
unit.utterance_translation: I will take it to my children.

unit.utterance: Esu fae je ton moron su enna su dhokumen alla.
unit.utterance_translation: You eat, and we will give you another for your children.

unit.utterance: Posa mora eshis?
unit.utterance_translation: How many children do you have?

unit.utterance: Exo mian korun je thk'o pallikaruk'a.
unit.utterance_translation: I have one girl and two boys.

unit.utterance: E, katse na fais je na mas istorisis kati je na dhokumen pu mian pittan ton moron su je pu tris el'es &na tus paris &na dhipnisun.
unit.utterance_translation: So, sit down to eat and tell us something and we'll give your children one pie and three olives each, so you can give it to them for dinner.

unit.utterance: O Yennaris ekraen llion xorton.
unit.utterance_translation: January had a little grass.

unit.utterance: *"Pos pai o Yennaris", lali tis, "areski su?"
unit.utterance_translation: "How is it with January", he says to her, "do you like him?"

unit.utterance: U, Panayia mu!
unit.utterance_translation: Oh, Mother of God!

unit.utterance: *Yati na men mu areski o Yennaris, polla kalos!
unit.utterance_translation: Why should I not like January, it is very good.

unit.utterance: E, o Fevraris pu ine mexismenos?
unit.utterance_translation: So, the drunk February?

unit.utterance: O Fevraris, enna kuchasun ta psumn'a, *yati na men m areski.
unit.utterance_translation: In February bread will be produced, why should I not like it?

unit.utterance: E, o Martis?
unit.utterance_translation: And March?

unit.utterance: (ekraten kutsullan ksistrashasmenin krittarin).
unit.utterance_translation: (he held a ripe grain of barley)

unit.utterance: E, nda o Martis en o kalos, pu fisa aeras je kuchazun ta krittarka je an'onnete i spora.
unit.utterance_translation: Ah, but March is the good one, when the wind blows and the barley and the seeds grow.

unit.utterance: O Aprillis, pu eshi tosin piran?
unit.utterance_translation: And April, when it's so hot?

unit.utterance: E, kala!
unit.utterance_translation: It is so!

unit.utterance: An men eshi etsi piran, *inda lois enn alonepsumen?
unit.utterance_translation: If it's not so hot, how are we going to thresh?

unit.utterance: E, o Mas, pu eshi tosin piran?
unit.utterance_translation: And May, when it's so hot?

unit.utterance: A, o Mas?
unit.utterance_translation: Ah, May?

unit.utterance: Enna mas feri ghrusomila, na mas feri agurak'a, na mas feri kolokudhia, freska faya na tromen!
unit.utterance_translation: He will bring us apricots, he will bring us cucumbers, he will bring us courgettes, fresh produce, so that we can eat!

unit.utterance: E, o Protoyunis?
unit.utterance_translation: So, and June?

unit.utterance: E, o Protoyunis na men eni, ponna mas feri sika, stafilin, po ula ta pramata!
unit.utterance_translation: Oh, if it were not for June, that will bring us figs, grapes, everything!

unit.utterance: E, kalan, o Dhefteroyunis?
unit.utterance_translation: Ah, ok, and July?

unit.utterance: A, o Dhefteroyunis, enna vkun paputsosika, enna vkun sika freska, enna vki stafilin, pattishes...
unit.utterance_translation: Ah, in July, prickly pears will appear, figs will appear, grapes, watermelons will appear.

unit.utterance: E, o Austos?
unit.utterance_translation: So, and August?

unit.utterance: E, nda o Austos en parkatu?
unit.utterance_translation: Ah, and is August unworthy?

unit.utterance: Prepi na ni j o Austos, ya na sirviri to psumin endaksi.
unit.utterance_translation: August must be there, to produce bread properly.

unit.utterance: E, o Oxtovris?
unit.utterance_translation: So, and October?

unit.utterance: E, nda o Oxtovris en parkatu?
unit.utterance_translation: Ah, but is October unworthy?

unit.utterance: Pu erkete o Oxtovris, o N'ovris je koma eshi stafilin?
unit.utterance_translation: That October, November comes, and still there are grapes around?

unit.utterance: Aresen su j o Oxtovris?
unit.utterance_translation: Did you like October too?

unit.utterance: Kalo!
unit.utterance_translation: Of course!

unit.utterance: E, o N'ovris?
unit.utterance_translation: So, and November?

unit.utterance: E, o N'ovris, k'on j an to vris!
unit.utterance_translation: Ah, November, ? if you find it.

unit.utterance: E, o Dhijevris?
unit.utterance_translation: So, and December?

unit.utterance: E, o Dhijevris, dhikeos po pospiren.
unit.utterance_translation: Ah, in December, just is the one that has sowed.

unit.utterance: Pravo!
unit.utterance_translation: Well done!

unit.utterance: Aresan su i minaes uli?
unit.utterance_translation: Did yo like all months?

unit.utterance: Malista, aresan mu, kalo!
unit.utterance_translation: Yes, of course I liked them.

unit.utterance: Edhoken tis tris pittes j enn'a el'es j edhoken tis je ambustan yematin lira xrisin.
unit.utterance_translation: He gave her three pies and nine olives, and he gave her also a box full with gold pound coins.

unit.utterance: Na pais esso su, na okis ton moron su na fasin tin pittan je tes el'es je na milisis ton pekk'on su: "akoute, pekk'a mu, pano, varte tris metanies kaxe enas" j akoma, an mboris, na kamis j esu tris metanies je tin ambustan tutin pu su dhokamen na tin valis puka sto maksilarin su je na sikoxis pu to proin na valis ta mora su na niftun je na ta valis na metan'asun pu tris metanies, akoma, an mboris, na metan'asis j esu.
unit.utterance_translation: Go home, give your children the pie and the olives to eat, and tell your children: "listen, my children, ?, make three repentances each" and still, if you can, you should make three repentances too, and this box that we gave you put it under your pillow, and get up in the morning and order you children to wash their faces, and order them to make three repentances, and if you can, repent too.

unit.utterance: Malista.
unit.utterance_translation: Ok.

unit.utterance: Je n anniksis tin ambustan j en yemati lires xrises, na pk'annis mian je na vrexunde thk'o je na ghorasis psum'a ton moron su na trosin, na men dhistixun.
unit.utterance_translation: And you should open the box, and it's full of golden pound coins, you take one, and two arise, and buy bread for your children, so that they can eat and not be unhappy.

unit.utterance: Ate, ame sto kalon!
unit.utterance_translation: Come on, leave, and blessed be your way.

unit.utterance: Sikonnete i yeneka j epien...
unit.utterance_translation: The woman got up and went.

unit.utterance: Mana, irtes?
unit.utterance_translation: Mother, you came back?

unit.utterance: Irta, mana mu.
unit.utterance_translation: I came, my dear (mana mu is an affectionate form of address).

unit.utterance: Na mian pittan esu je mian pittan o allos je mian tu allu je pu tris elies.
unit.utterance_translation: Here is one pie for you, and one for the other, and one for the other one and three olives each.

unit.utterance: Esuni, mana?
unit.utterance_translation: And you, mother?

unit.utterance: Eyoni et telo, mana mu.
unit.utterance_translation: I don't want any, my dear.

unit.utterance: Oi, mamma, na fais j esu!
unit.utterance_translation: No, mum, you should eat too.

unit.utterance: Ekopsan ta mora je ta tria po nan kommatuin j edhokan tis mammas tus je pu mian el'an.
unit.utterance_translation: All three of the children cut off one little piece, and gave it to their mother along with one olive each.

unit.utterance: Fae, mamma j esu, yati esu en pinas?
unit.utterance_translation: Eat mum, you too, why, aren't you hungry?

unit.utterance: Efaen i yeneka me ta mora tis.
unit.utterance_translation: The woman ate together with her children.

unit.utterance: Ate, mora mu, sikute pano, varte pu tris metanies je na ppesumen is tin dhinamin tu Theu, j irten to kkismettin sas, pekk'a mu.
unit.utterance_translation: Come, my children, get up, place each repentances each and let us lie in the power of God, because your fate is here, my children.

unit.utterance: Oi, mamma, pu dheka na valomen, oi mian!
unit.utterance_translation: No, mum, we should place ten each, not one!

unit.utterance: Emetan'asan ta mora, emetan'asen je jini, eppesan.
unit.utterance_translation: The children repented, she repented too, they lied down.

unit.utterance: Aman j eppesen to fos xame, "Sikute, mana mu, pano, sikute pano na niftite, na sastite je na metan'asete je na vrumen to xriman na sas ghoraso psumn'a na fate.
unit.utterance_translation: As soon as it became light (she said) "Get up, my children, get up so that you can wash your faces, get ready and repent, and we will find the money so that I can buy bread for you to eat.

unit.utterance: Malista, mamma.
unit.utterance_translation: Yes, mum

unit.utterance: Esikoxikan ta mora, eniftikan, extenistikan, estaxikan, emetan'asan, andis tris, evalan pu dheka, oi pu mian, je jini mazin.
unit.utterance_translation: The children got up, they washed their faces, they combed themselves, stood up, repented, instead of three they placed ten (repentances), not one each, and that together. (?)

unit.utterance: Anniksan tin ambustan, yemati lires xrises!
unit.utterance_translation: They opened the box, which was full of golden pound coins!

unit.utterance: E, mamma, emis epinasamen!
unit.utterance_translation: Oh, mum, we're hungry.

unit.utterance: Malista, mana mu, tora na pao dhame stin yitonissan mas na mas dhoki enan psumin dhanikon je eyo na pa na ghoraso sitarin na sas leso na trote
unit.utterance_translation: Ok, my children, I'll go now here to our neighbour, so that she can give us a loaf of bread on loan and I will go and buy wheat so that I can grind it and you can eat.

unit.utterance: Epien i yeneka.
unit.utterance_translation: The woman went.

unit.utterance: Kori yitonissa, parakalo na mu okis enan psumin j an eshis je sitarin, na mu pulisis tria kila.
unit.utterance_translation: You, neighbour, please, give me one loaf of bread, and if you have wheat, sell three kilos to me.

unit.utterance: Exo, kalo n exo!
unit.utterance_translation: I have it, what, should I not?!

unit.utterance: Ta rial'a na su ta oko.
unit.utterance_translation: I'll give you the money.

unit.utterance: Edhoken tis enan psumin, edhoken tis je tria kila sitarin.
unit.utterance_translation: She gave her a loaf of bread and three kilos of wheat as well.

unit.utterance: Epien i yeneka esso, emirasen ton moron tis psumin, efaasin, estaxin eplinnen to, aplosen to pa stes sakkulles, irten i adherfi tis.
unit.utterance_translation: The woman went home, passed the bread around to her children, they ate, she got up, washed it (the wheat), spread it on top of the bags, her sister came.

unit.utterance: Xa, eklepses to sitarin mu!
unit.utterance_translation: Ha, you stole my wheat!

unit.utterance: Yiati j en irtes na zimosis simera?
unit.utterance_translation: And why did you not come to knead today?

unit.utterance: Oi, arota tin yitonissan mu na is pos t aghorasa pu tin yitonissan mu to sitarin.
unit.utterance_translation: No, ask my neighbour, so that you can see I bought it from her, this wheat.

unit.utterance: E, eklepses ta rial'a mu!
unit.utterance_translation: Ah, you stole my money!

unit.utterance: *Je pu ta ishes esu ta rial'a j epk'axes sitarin j ekatses ta kopellukk'a ghiru ghiru je glepun to sitarin?
unit.utterance_translation: And where did you have the money and you bought wheat and you sat the children round it and they watch it?

unit.utterance: Akuse dha.
unit.utterance_translation: Listen here.

unit.utterance: Extes eplinnes ta sherka mu, andinakses tin pothk'an mu, to mandilin mu, eyoni epia j ivra ta mora mu stin karkolan j ekarterusan na tus kamo tin ghrutan na fasin.
unit.utterance_translation: Yesterday you washed my hands, you shook my apron and my scarf, I went and found my children on the bed, they were waiting for me to make the ghruta so they could eat.

unit.utterance: Embika esso.
unit.utterance_translation: I entered the house.

unit.utterance: O, mamma, andinakses tin jefalin su je ta pothk'a su je ta sherka su!
unit.utterance_translation: Oh, mum, you shook your head and your legs and your hands!

unit.utterance: Ti na kamo ye mu!
unit.utterance_translation: What can I do, my son!

unit.utterance: I thk'a sas etsi exelisen!
unit.utterance_translation: Your aunt wanted it this way!

unit.utterance: "E", ipun tus, "katsete, mana mu, mes stin karkolan, na pao daame stin yitonissan na tis po na mu oki enan psumin na sas fero na fate."
unit.utterance_translation: So, I told them, sit, my children, on the bed, I'll go here to the neighbour to tell her to give me some bread so that I can bring it to you to eat.

unit.utterance: Andis na pao stin yitonissan mu na yirepso psumin, etravisa makria na xaxo.
unit.utterance_translation: Instead of going to my neighbour and ask for bread, I went far away, in order to get lost.

unit.utterance: San epienna, ivra enan chatirin me eksi thrania je ishen dhodheka nomatus pano j ekathundan.
unit.utterance_translation: As I was going, I found a tent with six desks, and there were twelve people sitting there.

unit.utterance: "Kalispera, pathk'a", ipun tus.
unit.utterance_translation: Good evening, I told them.

unit.utterance: O, kalos tin, pos irtes os dha?
unit.utterance_translation: Oh, welcome, how did you come here?

unit.utterance: Epinases?
unit.utterance_translation: Are you hungry?

unit.utterance: Pino, kalo n pino!
unit.utterance_translation: I'm hungry, what, shouldn't I be?!

unit.utterance: E, eokan mu misin pittan je tris el'es.
unit.utterance_translation: So, they gave me half a pie and three olives.

unit.utterance: E, na ta pao ton moron mu.
unit.utterance_translation: So, to take to my children.

unit.utterance: Eshis polla mora?
unit.utterance_translation: Do you have many children?

unit.utterance: Exo mian korin je thk'o pallikarukk'a.
unit.utterance_translation: I have a daughter and two boys.

unit.utterance: Kala!
unit.utterance_translation: Ok!

unit.utterance: Je totes arotisan me *pos pai o ghronos.
unit.utterance_translation: And then they asked me, how the year goes.

unit.utterance: Kalo, polla kali!
unit.utterance_translation: Of course, they are very good!

unit.utterance: Aresan su i minaes je i dhodheka?
Kalo, aresan mu.
unit.utterance_translation: Of course, I liked them

unit.utterance: J edhokan mu mian ambustan lires na troo me ta pethk'a mu je na men erkume sto spitin su je na m eshis ulli mera na dhulefko nistijin je lierin je ton moron mu, allaxu, nakkon ghrutan ekopses tin je jinin.
unit.utterance_translation: And they gave me a box with pound coins so that I and my children can eat, and I don't come to your house, and you have me the whole day working on an empty stomach, and you stopped even the little ghruta for my children.

unit.utterance: Dhoksa si o Theos, anniksen to kkismettin ton pethk'on mu p allu.
unit.utterance_translation: God be praised, the fate of my children has turned, due to another source.

unit.utterance: E, na pao j eo, popse, kori.
unit.utterance_translation: Ah, I should go too, tonight, girl.

unit.utterance: E, lamne.
unit.utterance_translation: Ok, go.

unit.utterance: Tin nixtan oson j enixtosen, epk'aen tin stratan, epien ivren tus je jini tus minaes.
unit.utterance_translation: As soon as night fell, she went on the road, went and found the months as well.

unit.utterance: Kalispera, pethk'a!
unit.utterance_translation: Good evening, guys.

unit.utterance: O, kalos tin!
unit.utterance_translation: Ah, welcome.

unit.utterance: *Pos os dha, pinas?
unit.utterance_translation: How come you're here, are you hungry?

unit.utterance: Oi, dhoksa si o Theos, en pino!
unit.utterance_translation: No, thank God, I'm not hungry!

unit.utterance: *E, kalo, posa pethk'a eshis?
unit.utterance_translation: Ok, how many children do you have?

unit.utterance: Ena!
unit.utterance_translation: One!

unit.utterance: E, o Yennaris aresen su?
unit.utterance_translation: So, did you like January?

unit.utterance: U manulla mu, je o Yennaris pu tin kriotin, exumen therapian?
unit.utterance_translation: Oh my God, and what can one do against the January cold?

unit.utterance: J en s aresen?
unit.utterance_translation: So you did not like it?

unit.utterance: E, en m aresen, kalo!
unit.utterance_translation: Oh no, of course I did not like it!

unit.utterance: O Fervaris?
unit.utterance_translation: How about February?

unit.utterance: Shiru Shirottera!
unit.utterance_translation: Even worse!

unit.utterance: O Fervaris!
unit.utterance_translation: February!

unit.utterance: Meran nixtan jinos o anemos tu o pellomexismenos!
unit.utterance_translation: Day and night that crazy drunken wind!

unit.utterance: A, oste en su aresen me o Fervaris!
unit.utterance_translation: Oh, I see, you did not like February either!

unit.utterance: E, o Martis?
unit.utterance_translation: So, and March?

unit.utterance: E, inda o Martis pu to pornon pu tin kriotin psofa to ghadhurin j os to mesomerin vroma to pu tin piran.
unit.utterance_translation: Ah, but in March in the morning a donkey dies from the cold, and until noon it's so hot that it (March) makes it stink.

unit.utterance: A, en su aresen me jinos?
unit.utterance_translation: Ah, so you did not like that one either.

unit.utterance: Oi!
unit.utterance_translation: No!

unit.utterance: O Aprillis?
unit.utterance_translation: And April?

unit.utterance: Inda o Aprillis pu tin piran trexun ta ghromata pupano mas.
unit.utterance_translation: And April is so hot that the sweat flows from our bodies.

unit.utterance: E, o Mas?
unit.utterance_translation: And May?

unit.utterance: Je jinos ta idhia!
unit.utterance_translation: The same with him too!

unit.utterance: Telospandon en tis aresen enas minas!
unit.utterance_translation: Anyway, not one month did she like!

unit.utterance: Malista!
unit.utterance_translation: Ok!

unit.utterance: Edhokan tis mian ambustan.
unit.utterance_translation: The gave her a box.

unit.utterance: Na pais je na valis puka sto maksilarin su, amma men t aniksis je avrion pu to proin, oi jimesa pon to moron su je o andras su, na pais allon spitin je na vaoxis je na klioxis je n anniksis tin ambustan tutin, na vris to kkismettin su!
unit.utterance_translation: You go and put it under your pillow, but don't open it and tomorrow morning -not where your child and husband are, go to another house and close yourself and lock yourself inside, and open this box, to find your fate.

unit.utterance: Malista!
unit.utterance_translation: Ok!

unit.utterance: Pai pu to proin, esikoxiken, epien allon spitin.
unit.utterance_translation: Since early morning she went, got up and went to another house.

unit.utterance: Annii tin, kufaes, therka, dhropies!
unit.utterance_translation: She opens it - snakes, monsters, coin snakes!

unit.utterance: Amesos tin jenekan efaan tin.
unit.utterance_translation: Immediately they ate the woman.

unit.utterance: Efika tus jinus ji kaka j irta j ivra sas esas dha kala.
unit.utterance_translation: I left them there badly and came and found you here well.
